Built 1830. Inactive since 1986. Approx. 11 m (36 ft) round stone tower with lantern and gallery. Lighthouse painted white, gallery rail red. 

So not theopening I guess

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Looks like the Greenore hotel was only recently demolished www.argus.ie/lifestyle/permission-to-demolish-greenore-ho...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
2006 
The Greenore Hotel, built by The London and North Western Railway in the 1870s as one of the most imposing railway hotels in Ireland, and one of only a handful to be built of brick, located at Greenore Port in north Co Louth is to be demolished according to the website The El Paso Times. Apparently an article about the impending demolition has also appeared in the local newspaper
• To facilitate the speedy movement of passengers to and from the platforms, James Barton designed moving stairways, which are described and drawn in the Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers. These early versions of escalators would be of immense historical and technical importance if traces of them survived

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Would hazard that whatever was "going on", it may have had more (or at least as much) to do with the hotel than the lighthouse. Really disappointed to read ccferrie's link about the demolition. It looked like a fine building. The assessment of the National Inventory of Heritage and those fantastic looking "moving staircases" look great. Some great photos of the interior and events on the lawn. I particularly like this shot of the revolving sun houses on the lawn.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Could it be associated with this?

Greenore Golf Club was built by the London & North Western Railway Company which at this time co-owned the railway and the hotel. The golf course was first opened with 12 holes in October 1896

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Could be. It's definitely of the era. Dress/etc definitely stack up with a mid-1890s assessment. (Certainly these photos of the hotel/lawn from 1915 show a much more modern fashion.) I would wonder however why you'd have the event/band on the croquet lawn - rather than over at the golf course itself? (The course/clubhouse is a short walk away) Perhaps so the ladies could be involved? I am also intrigued by the tent/marquee down the road. Is it related to the event? Certainly there's as many people outside the hotel gates as inside...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Could be something to do with the Golf. This photo is 5335 in the collection, 5334 is the Golf House, Greenore See NLI cat entry Anyway photo is post October 1896...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
5333 is more Golf 
5332 is the Hotel

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: One of the flags being flown is the Coastguard flag. The others are a mix of letters and numeral pennants. I am not sure there is anything in the specific order of them - they are just "dressed overall". Ships, yachts, Coastguard stations dress overall for significant events - eg Queen's jubilees. Might this not be Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee on the 22 June 1897?

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: The sequence of flags does not particularly mean anything but there is a recommended sequence and certain dates on which this should be done sailingalmanac.com/Almanac/Reference/dressoverall.html

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: The Commissioners of Irish Lights became that from an earlier body in 1867. It is possible the large flag at the left is theirs at that time - it resembles the current Trinity House flag. Nowadays the Commisioners of Irish light maintain all the lighthouses around Ireland. They do have some history about the lights but I can't find anything around the 1890s. commissionersofirishlights.com/

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] Did we not establish that the photographer was in Belfast for the Diamond Jubilee?

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I did not know that. However that is the type of event that nautical establisments (lighthouses, coastguard stations) dress overall for so it must have been a pretty big occasion.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Pulling it back to Greenore for a minute, do we think this could've been the festivities around the launch of a new vessel or service by the L&NW? Or maybe something to do with the lifeboat? The lifeboat house is the building in the right-background next to the tent and some of those other flags. Perhaps a fundraiser or launch event for the lifeboat? It's behind the paywall, but the Irish Times has a feature from October of 1898 about some trials on the Greenore Lifeboat(?)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Hello! Sorry, been out all day. Will check Irish Times now...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] No go, I'm afraid! From the Irish Times of Tuesday, 18 October 1898:
During Saturday's gale the Greenore lifeboat was launched for quarterly practice, under the superintendence of Mr. Robert Baker, chief officer of coastguards, the hon. secretary of the Greenore Branch. The wind was east-north-east, blowing a fresh gale, with a very heavy sea running, notwithstanding which the boat was taken outside the bar lighthouse?/highshore?, a distance of over two miles dead to windward. The boat behaved splendidly. The crew now have the fullest confidence in her. The honorary secretary went out in the lifeboat, and expresses hemself perfectly satisfied with the boat's behaviour, both as to stability and seaworthiness.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 80878055@N00
comment._content: I cant contribute anything other than a photo I took of the lighthouse a few years ago.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Ah well. It was a long-shot. Not being nautical I wasn't sure whether "lifeboat tests" were a flag waving, tea drinking event where people shout "huzzah" at the launch. Or whether it was just a functional test. Sounds very much like the latter. Back to the drawing board again!
